tossups.question: An F-sharp minor piece with this nickname begins its last section with two rapid ascents by both hands up the keyboard, which respectively end with octave chords on C-sharp and F, and includes an A major mazurka. An orchestral piece named for this adjective opens with two shattering D minor chords in the strings outlining a descending fourth. A repeated A-major chord motif shifts to A minor over timpani in a symphony with this name, whose "old-fashioned" trio section depicts (*) children playing in sand. This word names Chopin's Opus 44 Polonaise ("poh-loh-NEZ") and a companion piece to the Academic Festival Overture. In the finale of a symphony with this nickname, a large mallet plays two or three "hammer blows of fate." For 10 points, give this common name of a Brahms overture and Mahler's sixth symphony.
tossups.answer: tragic [accept tragische; accept Tragic Polonaise, or Tragic Overture, or Tragic Symphony]

tossups.question: Two shrines in this country are the same distance apart as Safa and Marwah hills; a river shifted course to flow around one of those shrines in this country, thus "coming to" the man buried in it, a flag-bearer who was killed while bringing water. A mausoleum in this country is near the world's largest cemetery, known as the "Valley of Peace" or Wadi as-Salam. A site in this country is the destination of a pilgrimage whose name, meaning "forty", is (*) Arba'in. That pilgrimage is so named because it takes place forty days after the day of Ashura, which mourns a battle in this present-day country which martyred Ali's son Husayn. The cities of Najaf and Karbala are found in, for 10 points, what majority-Shi'a country, where they are both along the Euphrates river?
tossups.answer: Republic of Iraq [or Jumhuriyyah al-'Iraq; or Komarî Êraq]

tossups.question: This book notes that, when it is "impossible to distinguish a real from a fancied injury," each person risks having the "gates of paranoia" close on them. This book, which opens by noting its author had "begun...and torn it up five times," declares that the Third Reich makes "obsolete...any question of Christian superiority". Its narrator remarks that his host reminds him of "my father and me as we might have been" while recounting dinner in Chicago with Elijah Muhammad. This book's title comes from the (*) spiritual "Mary Don't You Weep". It includes a "Letter from a Region of my Mind" and a letter to the author's nephew which inspired Ta-Nehisi Coates' Between the World and Me, titled "My Dungeon Shook." For 10 points, name this book titled for a future racial conflict by James Baldwin.
tossups.answer: The Fire Next Time

tossups.question: The concentration of these two elements can be reduced by using an Olszewski tube. Anthropogenic interference with the biogeochemical cycling of these two elements comprises one of the nine "planetary boundaries". The abundance of these two elements are given by the 16 and 1 in a 106 to 16 to 1 ratio observed by Alfred Redfield. The plurality of non-point source (*) water pollution in the US is caused by surface runoff contaminated with these two elements; such pollution may lead to eutrophication. Potassium and these two elements are the most abundant components of commercial fertilizers. For 10 points, name these two elements, one of which has red and white allotropes, and the other of which bonds to hydrogen in ammonia.
tossups.answer: nitrogen and phosphorus [accept N and P]

tossups.question: A reception for this ruler was disrupted by Liberal street gangs in a brawl called the Night of the Broken Bottles. A priest called "Friar Mug" teamed up with northern landowners to form a short-lived confederation crushed by this ruler, who won favorable navigation rights in the Cisplatine War. After abdicating, this ruler fought for his daughter Maria in the Liberal War. Early in his reign, this ruler's chief advisor was a geologist whose plans for creating an interior capital were later adopted, named (*) José Bonifácio de Andrada ("zho-SAY boh-nee-FAH-see-ooh jeh an-DRAH-dah"). During the "Dia do Fico," this ruler announced that he would refuse to return to Europe; he later proclaimed "Independence or Death!" in the Cry of Ypiranga, severing his country from its Iberian colonizer. For 10 points, name this first emperor of Brazil.
tossups.answer: Dom Pedro I [or Peter I; prompt on Pedro or Peter]

tossups.question: This work's sculptor was inspired by the diversity of ages shown in Jean-Louis Ernest Meissonier's Le Campagne de France ("luh kahm-PAHN-yuh duh frons") and made 40 paper and clay sketches of heads to prepare. This sculpture, made at the suggestion of Joshua Benton Smith, displays the Latin motto of the Society of Cincinnati, which translates as "He forsook all to preserve the public weal". 34 stars line the top of this sculpture, which shows laurel branches in the right hand of the personified (*) Victory who flies over the main scene. This bronze relief, which is depicted in the first of Charles Ives' Three Pieces in New England, shows a procession down Beacon Street led by a man on horseback. Boston Common is home to, for 10 points, what Augustus Saint-Gaudens work which depicts the 54th Massachusetts and its colonel?
tossups.answer: Robert Gould Shaw Memorial [or Memorial to Robert Gould Shaw and the Massachusetts Fifty-Fourth Regiment; accept answers which indicate a memorial for Robert Gould Shaw; accept answers which indicate a memorial commemorating the 54th Massachusetts Regiment before "54th Massachusetts"]

tossups.question: In a 2012 paper, Michael Bobick analyzed the rise of this region's largest company through illegal cigarette and frozen food trade. Almost everything in this region is run by the company Sheriff, which also produces its iconic Kvint brandy. 1,500 troops making up the OGRT have occupied this region with the pretext of controlling an ammunition depot at Cobasna. This region attempted to shut down schools that taught using a Latin alphabet instead of (*) Cyrillic, in addition to cracking down on the spread of Romanian. This region's Bendery ("ben-derry") Military Museum and the parliament building in Tiraspol are among its many relics preserved from when it was a part of the Soviet Union. For 10 points, name this breakaway region which gets its name from the river that demarcates the Ukraine-Moldova border.
tossups.answer: Transnistria [or Pridnestrovie; accept Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic or PMR; prompt on Bessarabia] (The river that names Transnistria is the Dniester River.)

tossups.question: Since 2015, Jan Simek et. al have been documenting an early use of this man's inventions in a cave in Willstown, Alabama. This man wears a red turban and smokes a pipe while holding up his most famous invention in a painting by Charles Bird King. It is unsure whether Major Ridge cut off this man's fingertips after he was accused of witchcraft, despite having earlier served under Ridge in the Creek War. This man convinced Elias Boudinot ("boo-dee-NOH") to set up a (*) newspaper in New Echota that became the first Native American newspaper. Later, he worked with Jesse Bushyhead to form a united government for his tribe in Oklahoma. With his daughter A-Ko-Ya, this man came up with a system of "talking leaves" that included 85 symbols. For 10 points, name this man who invented the Cherokee syllabary.
tossups.answer: Sequoyah [accept George Gist or George Guess]

tossups.question: This poet uses an analogy with Einstein's relativity to explain how there is no such thing as "free verse" in his essay "The Poem as a Field of Action". This author repeatedly asks "Which shore?" in a poem which declares that "The sky / where Watteau hung a lady's / slipper" is graced by the "blossoms" of a lady's thighs. This author developed his "triadic line" style in a collection whose title poem describes the "scattering of tall trees" in a "muddy field" which is (*) "by the road to the contagious hospital". A Charles DeMuth painting was inspired by this poet's line "I saw the figure five in gold". His collection Spring and All includes a meditation on an object "Glazed with rain / besides the white chickens". For 10 points, name this poet who wrote that "so much depends" on the title vehicle in "The Red Wheelbarrow".
tossups.answer: William Carlos Williams [or W. C. Williams; prompt on Williams]

tossups.question: In the metabolism of naphthalene, this functional group is replaced with a hydroxyl in the NIH shift, which is named for its discovery at the National Institutes of Health. One reason polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons are carcinogenic is that their arene groups are directly metabolized to compounds with this functional group by cytochrome P450 enzymes. Catalytic amounts of diethyl tartrate and titanium isopropoxide enable the enantioselective synthesis of these compounds via (*) oxidation of allylic alcohols. Peroxyacids like mCPBA convert alkenes to this functional group, which readily forms 1,2-diols upon hydrolysis due to relief of ring strain caused by 60 degree bond angles. For 10 points, an oxygen atom bonds to two adjacent carbon atoms in what functional group, a type of cyclic ether?
tossups.answer: epoxides [prompt on cyclic ethers; do not accept or prompt on "esters"]

tossups.question: In an incident during this conflict widely mocked by the press, a bumpy road made it impossible for a truck-mounted gunner to aim, so his target managed to damage the steering wheel and the truck crashed into a fence. Its losing commander wrote of tank-like invulnerability of this war's victors, who were like "Zulus whom even dum-dum bullets could not stop". George Pearce started this conflict after World War I veterans settled near Campion in the (*) Wheatbelt regions weren't given promised subsidies; G.P.W. Meredith then implemented their idea of using machine guns in a similar manner to how Turks shot at them at Gallipoli. Massive damage on crops and rabbit-control fences by migrating wildlife prompted, for 10 points, what farcically inept Australian attempt to cull a large flightless bird?
tossups.answer: Great Emu War

tossups.question: According to the symbiont hypothesis, one species evolved this behavior because they lose microbes from molting and must regain them via anal trophallaxis. In one species, this behavior coevolved with a "shoving" behavior to promote activity in the unusual "disperser" morph, which evolved to reduce inbreeding. This behavior is unusually present in pistol shrimp in the genus Synalpheus, which use its "fortress defense" type. The only mammals to display this behavior are the Damaraland and (*) naked mole rats. The evolution of this behavior was promoted by haplodiploid sex determination in hymenopterans. Cooperative brood rearing, organization into colonies, and division of labor into reproductive and non-reproductive groups are traits of, for 10 points, what behavior used by ants and bees?
tossups.answer: eusociality [prompt on descriptive answers like colony formation or having a queen and worker castes; prompt on social behavior/organization; prompt on altruism or kin selection] (The first clue is about how termites must repopulate their gut flora by pooping into each other's butts.)

tossups.question: A pamphlet by this author purports to tell the true story of the possibly-transgender Mary Hamilton, who was convicted for marrying Anna Price. This author ends a chapter with "Here the Graces think proper to end their description" after a lady "unmask[s] the royal battery," before cutting to a conversation in the kitchen where the characters hear again of the Man of the Hill. A novel by this author of The Female Husband features a plot concocted by Lord (*) Fellamar and Lady Bellaston to marry off a huntsman's daughter, so that the lady can have the sole attention of Bridget's bastard son. That comic novel by this author concludes with the marriage of Sophia Western to the title character, who is raised by Squire Allworthy as a foundling. For 10 points, name this author of Tom Jones.
tossups.answer: Henry Fielding

tossups.question: After being baptized in secret, a king of these people hired monks named Clement and Naum to baptize them, occasioning a mass pagan rebellion. Subsequently, a dispute over Catholic missionary work among these people led to the Photian schism. Cultural unification of these people, ruled by the Dulo clan, with their subjects was aided by literary schools such as Ohrid. The Paulicians may have inspired a Gnostic, dualistic sect which arose among these people called (*) Bogomilism. These originally-Turkic people became Orthodox Christians and sponsored the development of the Cyrillic script under their king Boris I, thus forming a unique culture with their South Slavic subjects. For 10 points, Byzantine emperor Basil II was known as the "slayer" of what people who lived north of Constantinople?
tossups.answer: Bulgars [or Bulgarians; prompt on Slavs; prompt on Turkic peoples before "Turkic"]

tossups.question: Susumu Ōno speculated that this language provided an ancient substrate of both Japanese and Korean, as suggested by the similarity of Korean eonni ("un-ni") to this language's word for "sister-in-law". This language, whose name for itself ends with an unusual voiced retroflex approximant, alters the meaning of words by applying dental, alveolar ("al-VEE-oh-lur"), and palatal ("PALL-ah-tul") nasal phonemes. This language's writing system is an abugida visualized using "body alphabets" or mei ezhuththukkal ("may eh-ROO-thoo-kul") and derived from the Pallava script. Its oldest attested writings are the (*) Sangam literature, including its Five Great Epics. This is the second-most widely spoken and oldest Dravidian language. Its word Eelam refers to Sri Lanka. For 10 points, name this language whose name precedes "Nadu" in the name of a South Indian state.
tossups.answer: Tamil [or Tamizh ("zh rhymes with the r in run"); accept Tamil Nadu]

tossups.question: In one film, three friends take a trip to the wilderness before leaving for this war, during which one of them denies another a pair of spare boots, saying "this is this". The opening sequence of another film set during this war transitions from a shot of a whisky glass, to one of a man lying in bed with a cigarette, to that man's eyes staring up at a ceiling fan. In a sequence from that film set during this war, a man peers through binoculars at a compound littered with lion statues as his (*) boat glides toward a throng of men with white ash smeared on their chest. Soldiers slap a man and force him to play Russian roulette in a film set during this war titled The Deer Hunter. In another film set during it, the "Ride of the Valkyries" accompanies helicopters destroying a coastal village. For 10 points, what war is depicted in Frank Coppola's film Apocalypse Now?
tossups.answer: Vietnam War [or Nam; or Second Indochina War; or Resistance War Against America; or Chiến tranh Việt Nam; prompt on invasion of Cambodia or Indochina War]

tossups.question: Offerings at a sanctuary in this location included knucklebones used for ritual gambling. An annual procession to this location reportedly saw people inscribe letters with the ashes of burnt offerings that were unchanged when they returned. This non-Delphi location had games honoring Apollo near a shrine to Delphic Apollo, the Pythion. Various towns near this location, such as Leibethra, were ascribed the birth and burial of (*) Orpheus. Homer gives this location the epithet "cloud-dark" but says that it's surrounded by "cloudless aether". This location is guarded by the Horae. After his death, Heracles is allowed to enter this location. Zeus sends a gadfly to prevent Bellerophon from reaching this location by stinging Pegasus. For 10 points, name this mountain that's home to the Greek gods.
tossups.answer: Mount Olympus [or Olympos; or Olympus Mons; or Olimbos; or Olibos; before "games", antiprompt on Agios Antonios]

tossups.question: Whether the square of a normalized form of this quantity is bigger or smaller than the strength parameter of an inverse-cube force determines the shape of the resulting Cotes spiral. This quantity is squared in the numerator of the "centrifugal barrier" term appearing in the effective potential. The "specific" form of this pseudovector quantity is denoted h in orbital mechanics. Cross-products with this quantity appear in the definitions of both the (*) Laplace-Runge-Lenz and eccentricity vectors; all three vectors are constants of the motion for two bodies interacting via gravity. The conservation of this quantity implies the "equal areas in equal time" rule expressed by Kepler's second law. Torque is the time derivative of, for 10 points, what rotational quantity given by "r cross p"?
tossups.answer: angular momentum [or rotational momentum; accept specific angular momentum; prompt on L or h; do not accept or prompt on "momentum"]

tossups.question: This philosopher's aesthetics distinguished between classical, romantic, and symbolic art and argued that classical art was the home of "ideal beauty". This philosopher's claim that art "in its highest vocation...remains for us a thing of the past" is examined by considering Andy Warhol's Brillo Boxes in Arthur Danto's essay on "The End of Art". This thinker argued that the pathos of ancient Greek characters articulated his notion of "ethical life," which he conceived of as "the concept of (*) freedom developed into the existing world" through family, civil society, and the state. He gave lectures on aesthetics and history to his students in Heidelberg and Berlin, and described both using his concept of dialectic. For 10 points, name this German idealist who wrote The Phenomenology of Spirit.
tossups.answer: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

tossups.question: Eugene O'Neill remarked that seeing Alla Nazimova perform this character's role 10 times sparked his "first conception of a modern theatre". A 1970 production at London's National Theatre by Ingmar Bergman starred Maggie Smith as this character. This character repeatedly rebuffs a man's attempt to make her his mistress by saying that he wants to be the "cock in the basket" and often describes a writer as having "vine-leaves in his hair". This character is told to "think of (*) Aunt Rina!" as she plays a "wild dance" on the piano. Thea attempts to reconstruct the manuscript burned by this character, who convinces its author Eilert ("EYE-lurt") to commit suicide. Judge Brack tries to blackmail, for 10 points, what unhappy wife of Jorgen Tesman, who shoots herself in the Henrik Ibsen play titled for her?
tossups.answer: Hedda Gabler [or Hedda Tesman; prompt on Gabler or Tesman]

bonuses.leadin: The central couple of this story hears a "fine crash from the piano" after wishing for 200 pounds. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: M. R. James [or Montague Rhodes James; prompt on James]
parts: Name this W. W. Jacobs story which ends with a painful cry from Mrs. White as she opens the front door to greet her mutilated son Herbert.

Some of England's most chilling ghost stories were written by this author of Ghost Stories of an Antiquary, whose stories often involve an academic who invokes the wrath of a spirit, as in "The Mezzotint".
This author parodied the ghost story in a work whose characters refuse to believe that a ghost inhabits Canterville Chase. His other Gothic works include The Picture of Dorian Grey.

bonuses.leadin: In this year, Aubrey Pollard, Carl Cooper, and Fred Temple were killed by police officers in the Algiers Motel Incident. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Romney [accept George Wilcken Romney or Willard Mitt Romney]
Kerner Commission [or National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders]
parts: Detroit experienced destructive race riots in its 12th Street during the "long, hot summer" of what year?
As Governor of Michigan, a politician with this surname called in the National Guard during the riots. His son was a former governor of Massachusetts and 2012 Republican presidential candidate.
Lyndon Johnson created this commission to investigate the causes of the 1967 race riots. It reported that "our nation is moving toward two societies, one black, one white — separate and unequal".

bonuses.leadin: You're the president of GT Quizbowl and your BuzzAnalytics software backlog has gotten too long. For 10 points each:
parts: To speed up the backlog, you integrate the "unit" form of this process into practices to help check if the neg prediction code is working. Unfortunately, Hari negs 100 times to break the system.
Luckily for you, GT Quizbowl uses this adaptive planning development approach popularized in a namesake manifesto that emphasizes flexibility and continual iteration.
Since GT kids are visual learners, you use this lean method borrowed from the automotive industry, which limits in-progress work and visualizes backlogs on a namesake board.

bonuses.leadin: These events were likely central to Proto-Indo-European religion, whose reconstructed term for them refers to drunkenness. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: horse sacrifice [accept any answer which refers to killing a horse; accept "stallion" or "mare" in place of "horse"; accept ashvamedha; prompt on October Horse or Equus October; prompt on animal sacrifice; do not accept or prompt on answers explicitly mentioning any non-horse animal]
Ireland [or Éire; accept Ulster or Ulaidh; accept Tyrconnell or Tír Chonaill; accept County Donegal or Contae Dhún na nGall]
parts: Identify these events performed to honor Mars during a festival on October 15. In Vedic India, one was done at the end of a year-long roaming period to confirm a king's rule.
Greeks preserved a memory of funerary horse sacrifices in the Iliad's account of the funeral of this lover of Achilles who was killed by Hector.
Giraldus writes that new rulers of a kingdom in this European region had sex with a mare that was then dismembered and cooked in a cauldron. This region's High Kings were crowned at Tara.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about systems of logic with increasing numbers of allowed values:
answers_sanitized: Charles Sanders Peirce (That essay is "How to Make Our Ideas Clear.")
parts: In standard Boolean logic, numbers can only take on these two values, which indicate "True" and "False".

This American philosopher's system of three-valued logic uses the symbols V, L, and F to indicate values of "True," "Indeterminate," and "False". In an essay for Popular Science, he proposed that logic should aim at "clearness of apprehension".
This Azerbaijani logician and mathematician developed what he called "fuzzy logic," a generalization of Boolean logic which allows any intermediate value between 0 and 1, to represent vagueness.

bonuses.leadin: This character initially ignores a gift which turns out to be a moving-picture machine that plays Mickey-Mouse and Popeye cartoons. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Heart is a Lonely Hunter
parts: Name this character who visits a ten-cent shop to get his photo taken after pay days at the jewelry store. He becomes a kleptomaniac and starts urinating in public after recovering from a stomach problem.
Spiros Antonapoulos dies in an asylum in this novel. Its original title, The Mute, refers to its protagonist John Singer, who commits suicide after learning of Spiros's death.
The Heart is a Lonely Hunter is by this Georgia-born Southern Gothic author of The Ballad of the Sad Cafe.

bonuses.leadin: The commutator of these two quantities equals one. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: ladder operators [accept both the raising and lowering operators, accept both the creation and annihilation operators]
quantum harmonic oscillators [accept simple harmonic oscillators, accept QHO or SHO]
parts: Name these quantities, which are used in the so-called "algebraic method" to factor a Hamiltonian given by (pause) p squared over 2m, (pause) plus m times omega squared times x squared, where omega is the angular frequency.
The ladder operators allow one to elegantly compute the ground state energy of the "quantum" version of these systems, whose restoring force is given by Hooke's Law.
Multiplying the raising operator on the right by the lowering operator gives this operator, which acts on a state to return the energy level the state is in.

bonuses.leadin: A song in this genre describes a "quiet night of quiet stars" around Mount Corcovado ("kor-koh-VAH-doo"). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this genre of music whose standards include "Chega da Saudade" ("SHEH-gah dah sau-DAH-jee"), which was written by João Gilberto ("zhuh-WOW zheel-BAIR-too"). Its other standards include "Desafinado" ("des-AH-fee-NAH-doo").
Accompanists in bossa nova songs often play this instrument without a plectrum. A "Portuguese" variety of this instrument that is pear-shaped consists of 12 steel strings.
Bossa nova is often compared to this expressive, melodic genre of Portuguese vocal music, whose typically sad themes are similar to those of Brazilian choros ("SHOW-roos").

bonuses.leadin: The Special Air Service developed out of a scouting unit that fought in this country. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Chin Peng [or Ong Boon Hua; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this present-day country where communist forces fought the British Empire during a namesake "emergency". So-called "New Villages" were created to relocate Chinese immigrants in this country.
General Harold Briggs approved the use of this chemical to destroy jungles during the Malayan Emergency. It was more famously used in the Vietnam War.
This leader of the Malaysian Communist Party instigated the Malayan Emergency. He had earlier assisted Freddie Spencer Chapman in fighting the Japanese in Malaysia's jungles.

bonuses.leadin: When using normal playing cards, this game is typically played by adding a Joker to the deck. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Old Maid [do not reveal this answer otherwise, but prompt on Black Peter]
Black Peter [or Zwarte Piet; prompt on Peter or Pete]
Jack of Spades [or knave of spades; or valet of spades; prompt on jack or knave or valet by asking "of what suit?"] (This is why the game is called "jackass" in some countries.)
parts: Give the common American name of this card game in which players continually play pairs of cards until one is left with the card representing the namesake woman in their hand.

A variant of "Old Maid" in Europe is often named for this soot-covered helper of Santa Claus. Many activists have protested the Dutch tradition of people donning blackface to depict this man in parades.

In many variants of Black Peter, the namesake character is represented by this playing card. In some decks, this playing card depicts Ogier ("oh-zhee-AY"), a legendary knight from Charlemagne's court.

bonuses.leadin: Double bass arpeggios, followed by an unusual contrabassoon solo, open this composer's Piano Concerto for the Left Hand, dedicated to the one-armed pianist Paul Wittgenstein. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this composer who used a constant snare drum ostinato in his piece Boléro.
This composer, whose Diversions for Piano Left Hand and Orchestra are also for Wittgenstein, adapted a rondeau from Purcell's Abdelazer for another of his pieces.

The movement "with fire and power" ends this Austrian composer's C-sharp major Piano Concerto for the Left Hand for Wittgenstein. He wrote the opera Die tote Stadt ("dee TOH-tuh SHTAHT") before fleeing to Hollywood to write film scores.

bonuses.leadin: This social scientist distinguished "individualist" and "federalist" tendencies in trade unions in her book The Cooperative Movement in Great Britain. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: London School of Economics [or LSE, or The London School of Economics and Political Science]
parts: Name this British socialist who coined the term "collective bargaining". She and her husband were key leaders of the Fabian Society.

The Webbs and other Fabians used an endowment from Henry Hutchinson's legacy to found this institution, which is often grouped with Oxford and Cambridge as the "golden triangle" of British research universities.
Among the faculty that the Webbs recruited to LSE was this Polish-born anthropologist who wrote Argonauts of the Western Pacific.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the Confederación Nacional del Trabajo ("trah-BAH-hoh"), or CNT:
parts: Unions such as the CNT exemplify the merger of this ideology with anarchism. This ideology advocates that labor unions use strikes for workers to seize the means of production.
The CNT was founded following a 1910 workers' congress in this city. A 1909 general strike resulted in the "Tragic Week" in this capital of Catalonia.

One of the CNT's biggest victories came when a power company in Barcelona, which was named for being located in this country, lowered the length of the work day to eight hours following a 1919 strike.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the theory of oral-formulaic composition of epic poems:
answers_sanitized: poetic feet [or metrical feet; accept foot for "feet"]
Serbs [or Serbians, or Srbi; accept Croats; accept Serbo-Croatians or Serbo-Croatians or Hrvatska; prompt on Slavs or Slavic people or South Slavs; do not accept or prompt on "Balkans"]
parts: The theory argues that epithets, such Homer's "rosy-fingered dawn," served as these devices to help poets recall names. Their name comes from the Greek for "memory".

The theory argues that using a fixed number of these metric units per line helped poets remember lines. Typically, these units consist of one stressed and one unstressed syllable, so five are in a line of iambic pentameter.
The theory was inspired by Milman Parry's studies of this ethnic group's epics, such as The Building of Skadar, which are performed by bards on the gusle ("GOO-leh").

bonuses.leadin: This model is mathematically analogous to the Monod equation and the Langmuir isotherm. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: dissociation constant [or Kd; prompt on equilibrium constant or K]
parts: Name this model, which can be derived from the steady-state approximation. The Hill equation reduces to this model when the Hill coefficient equals 1.
Michaelis-Menten kinetics models the rate of reactions that occur at the active sites of these substances.
For a solution of enzyme and ligand, when exactly half the enzymes are bound to a ligand, the concentration of free ligand must equal this value.

bonuses.leadin: This place lends its name to a Digambara ("dee-GAHM-buh-ruh") temple in Uttar Pradesh, which reflects it with a huge depiction of Mount Meru at its center. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Jambudvīpa [or Jambudweep; prompt on dvipa or dweep]
trees [accept jambu trees, jamun trees, blackberry trees, plum trees, fig trees, or fruit trees; accept Bodhi Tree]
parts: Name this "world-island" or "continent" where humans live in Jain and Hindu cosmology.

Some conceptions of Jambudvīpa consider it to be one of these objects, five of which are among the nine bodies called Navagraha. Like the Romans, Hindus named a red one of these objects for a god of war.
The name Jambudvīpa literally means "island of jamun," which is a variety of these objects. A descendant of a sacred one of these objects from Bodh Gaya is housed in the Mahabodhi temple.

bonuses.leadin: A victory stela created by this empire depicts one of its rulers defeating the Lullubi people of the Zagros. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Akkadian empire [or Agade] (The unnamed ruler is Sargon the Great.)
Pharaoh of Egypt (The two pharaohs in the question are Menes and Ramesses the Great)
parts: Name this empire, which reached its greatest extent under Naram-Sin. One of its earlier rulers served as cup-bearer to Ur-Zababa of Kish.

Some chronicles describe Naram-Sin defeating Manium, often equated with a holder of this title, during his invasion of Magan. A later holder of this title won the Battle of Kadesh against the Hittites.
The fall of the Akkadian empire was blamed on these people from the Zagros Mountains. According to the Weidner Chronicle, Marduk summoned them twice to punish Naram-Sin.

bonuses.leadin: Paintings in this style include Bridget Riley's 1961 Movement in Squares, which varies the width of the squares to create the illusion of a vanishing point. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this style of art which makes prominent use of distorted geometric forms. Its practitioners include Josef Albers.

Op art came to prominence after a MoMA exhibition of Riley's works titled for a "responsive" example of these objects. The French phrase trompe l'oeil ("tromp loy") refers to art that "deceives" these objects.
One of the earliest op-art works is a 1937 Victor Vasarely painting which shows two of these non-tiger animals overlapping against a black background.

bonuses.leadin: In one of this author's novels, when Father Vincent is thanked for his aid, he says "we do what is in us, and why it is in us, that is also a secret". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this South African author of Cry, the Beloved Country.
In Cry, the Beloved Country, Father Vincent helps this priest, who earlier travels to Johannesburg. This man's son Absalom murders the liberal white man Arthur Jarvis.

After Stephen prays following Absalom's death, the novel concludes by speaking of this concept's "bondage". The passage that gives the novel its title, which follows Jarvis's death, describes the "unborn child" as the "inheritor" of this concept.

bonuses.leadin: Alpha-beta unsaturated compounds with this electron-withdrawing group can, much like analogous carbonyls ("car-buh-NEELS"), serve as Michael acceptors. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: cyano group [or cyanide; prompt on nitrile]
parts: Name this group, which serves as a nucleophile to help elongate an aldose in the Kiliani-Fischer synthesis.
Like most electron-withdrawing groups, cyano groups direct electrophilic aromatic substitutions to this position, which is two carbons away on a benzene ring.
An alkene with one cyano group attached to each carbon makes an excellent dienophile in this cycloaddition reaction, which forms cyclohexene derivatives.
